thread.title: Wildfire smoke linked to IVF challenges, study finds | News | bozemandailychronicle.com
thread.title_full: Wildfire smoke linked to IVF challenges, study finds | News | bozemandailychronicle.com

author: Lilly Keller
title: Wildfire smoke linked to IVF challenges, study finds | News | bozemandailychronicle.com
text:
Wildfire smoke impacts on IVF pregnancy Women undergoing fertility treatment in wildfire-prone areas may face added challenges in conceiving due to poor air quality, according to a recent study conducted by researchers at Oregon Health & Science University.
The study, published in the journal Fertility & Sterility, examined the impact of unhealthy air quality from the 2020 Labor Day wildfires — which burned over 1 million acres in Oregon — on patients undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment.
Researchers studied 69 patients who underwent ovarian stimulation and IVF treatment during the six weeks leading up to and after the 2020 wildfires, which caused 10 days of hazardous air quality in southern Oregon. The findings revealed that poor air quality negatively impacted both the treatments and its effectiveness.
Specifically, patients exposed to wildfire smoke had fewer blastocysts —clusters of 150 to 200 cells essential for conceiving — compared to those who were not exposed, who had more blastocysts.
During IVF treatments, patients receive hormone injections for one to two weeks to stimulate egg production. The eggs are then retrieved and fertilized to develop into blastocysts, which can become embryos and, eventually, fetuses.
In 2022, IVF-assisted pregnancies represented 2.5% of all births, according to the American Society for Reproductive Medicine .
Dr. Molly Kornfield, the study’s lead author and assistant professor of reproductive endocrinology and infertility at the OHSU Center for Women’s Health, launched the research after being four weeks pregnant in Portland during the 2020 wildfires. She wanted to better understand the effects of poor air quality on IVF.
“Most of the data out there is on chronic air pollution, so we look at cities chronically exposed, like New York City and Los Angeles, whereas Portland is a metropolitan area of good air quality. So it’s this really unique opportunity to look at this place with good air quality and then 10 days of really poor air quality, and [see] what impact does that have,” she said
Kornfield said that while most patients still became pregnant, and fertility clinics monitor air quality closely, she advises women undergoing IVF in wildfire-affected areas to use air filtration systems, limit time outside and wear an N95 mask when going outdoors.
Although the study didn’t address the impact of wildfire smoke on traditional pregnancies, Kornfield said other research shows pregnant women are also vulnerable to poor air quality.
A 2023 study published in Cureus: Journal of Medical Science suggests that air pollution may harm lung development indirectly by causing low birth weight, premature birth or impaired immune system development.
Montana is no stranger to poor air quality from wildfire smoke originating from within the state and from Canada. In July, residents of Gallatin County lived with air quality ranging from moderate to unhealthy due to ongoing fires alongside scorching heat and minimal precipitation.
Bozeman’s air quality scored a 60 and was of moderate quality on Thursday afternoon, according to an air quality map published by the federal government at www.airnow.gov .
The government’s air quality monitoring standards includes six quality levels: good, 0-50; moderate, 51-100; unhealthy for sensitive groups, 101-150; unhealthy, 151-200; very unhealthy, 201-300; and hazardous, 301 and higher.
The following values were recorded Thursday afternoon for these cities:
Big Sky: 60 Livingston: 60 Helena: 53 Great Falls: 62 Missoula: 53 Billings: 61 Denver, Colorado: 50 Boise, Idaho: 72 Seattle, Washington: 46 Portland, Oregon: 37 Los Angeles, California: 67 San Francisco, California: 14 A 2016 study found that climate change doubled the number of large fires in the western U.S. between 1984 and 2015 by accelerating the drying of organic matter, including ground and surface fuels. A 2021 study further confirmed that climate change has been the main driver of increased fire weather in the region.
Despite wildfires and smoke becoming a part of daily life nationwide, the study found that treatments improved once the wildfires ended.
“As of anything in health, it’s all in moderation, and different people have different risk factors and different abilities to tolerate poor air quality,” Kornfield said. “But I think, in general, minimizing exposure as much as possible is probably best, not just for reproduction, but for for all facets of health.”
